utterances.sentences: Well, what is your idea to find that?

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: Well, go -- across-the-board cuts. Find ways that we can go find programs to eliminate, whatever it takes to go find...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But no one has proposed that.

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: Oh, sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You know what I'm saying? Congressman, no one has proposed that. They just say, give us $5.6 billion. I'm not saying -- it's a worthy goal and the security is a legitimate issue, but Republicans haven't come up with how to pay for that, or just as Democrats weren't coming up with ways to pay for lots of things in the past. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } But it's like we're just made of money. And this is how we have a record debt level. This is why we have the Federal Reserve boss talking today about debt worries him more than anything else.

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: It's -- there's no question that debt is one of the fundamental issues. It's our -- a national security crisis. In fact, the defense secretary said it's one of the biggest issues we face. We need to balance the budget.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you never do. You never, ever do.

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: But the first -- the first duty of government, the first duty of government is to defend the United States of America from enemies, foreign and domestic. And that includes national security, and that includes border security. So we should do that. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And the includes our financial security as well.

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: This is an urgent need, but you guys wouldn't like it if it turned around on you, and a Democratic administration was pushing what it said was vital, vital, vital programming, and you were arguing for the same thing, that they're going to hold the government hostage to getting that.

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: Neil, I'm happy to support any legislation, any legislation that will cut other federal government spending in order to fund security at the border and provide our Border Patrol agents what they need to have more agents, more wall security, more cameras, more personnel.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: No, I understand what you're saying. And these are all meritorious goals. But if a Democratic administration were to come in and argue the same -- and we have seen this happen with both in the past, sir -- that, all of a sudden, they're going to make the same pitch and hold the same government hostage to the same urgently needed initiative. And I'm just saying that, at what point do we just say, this is adding up, $5 billion here, $6 billion here? And, by the way, this $5.6 billion is a down payment on something that's a fraction of the cost being mentioned right now. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: I could not agree more. We must start with the income that we have, the $3.5 trillion, defend the United States of America abroad and here at home, and that includes border security, and then do the rest that we need to do. But we need to secure the border now. And you know and I know it's a crisis. And we need to balance the budget. We need to have health care freedom, and then get Washington, D.C., out of the way. These are things we can do if we'd all just come together and agree on the common points and the commonsense answers the American people want.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, Congressman, thank you very much. Fair and balanced, we're going to hear from the Democratic side on all of this. And fair and balanced, we're also going go back in time, not necessarily giving my opinion or my guests' opinion, but the movers and shakers and what they had said on this very issue. Not my words, their words. Not my words, the president's words. Not my words, Nancy Pelosi's words. Not my words, Chuck Schumer's words. Not opinion, fact, statements made then vs. now that don't add up -- more after this. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, welcome back, everyone. Day 20, and the government is still partially shut down, at least a quarter of it. Some are saying that the spreading effect of this is actually shutting down a third of it. I have no idea. This much, I do have an idea of, the inconsistent positions that show that these two sides are not that far apart, a president who is open right now, it would seem, to recognizing that Mexico isn't going to pay for wall, and Democrats who seen, at least given some past statements we played a little earlier, recognize the severity of what's happening at our nation's border. So they shared common concerns then. They actually share these same common concerns now. And a lot of this to me just seems like professional wrestling, where each one plays a part, and the media complies, goes along, and continues spouting the same game, depending on their biases, whether they're for or against the president, for or against the Democrats. I'm telling you, folks, I have watched this and listened to this carefully. They both are playing a lot of games here. Republican strategist Noelle Nikpour, Democratic strategist Scott Levenson, and Axios' Shannon Vavra. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Shannon, I want to get your take on what's going on here, because there is more common ground than either lets on, Democrats who bemoan the fact that the president's manufacturing a crisis, when, little more than a few months ago, it was a crisis. The president saying, we're going to get that wall, the Mexicans are going to pay for it, now saying that he never intended the Mexicans or thought the Mexicans would. So, they're both talking past each other. And they're both zooming us.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON VAVRA, AXIOS
utterances.sentences: The common ground here, you're right, is that there is a humanitarian crisis at the border. And it's only getting worse. But the bottom line here, for the political stance, is that we're at a standstill, right? Nancy Pelosi has said she's not going to fund the border wall, and President Trump says that he wants a wall or there's no deal. And we see him leaning into this idea that he could declare a national emergency over the border wall funding at this point, and he confirmed that this morning.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right. Noelle, I'm just wondering who wins here, because the original surveys that were done showed that the Republicans were botching this. Now, they're all over the map, these numbers. But now, in some of the later ones, both sides are getting equally blamed. The longer this drags on, I cannot see how both sides escape the wrath of voters. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: NOELLE NIKPOUR, REPUBLICAN FUND-RAISER
utterances.sentences: You know what? The longer this does drag on, Neil, the longer nobody really wins in the end. And the argument gets diluted along the way. And people get really tired of watching the two sides argue. And I think that's -- earlier, you were saying that the Democrats say one thing and then backtrack. And then Trump says something about Mexico paying for the wall and then backtracks.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: It's all right. And I remember that great Ronald Reagan thing. I evolved. That's fine. I evolved on that position. Of course, he was talking about starting out as an FDR Democrat and then, of course, as a conservative Republican.

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But, Scott Levenson, where does this put Democrats right now? They're not budging. Obviously, the president isn't going to budge. The longer this drags on, is the party thinking or some of your Democratic colleagues thinking they're having the advantage, or what?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT LEVENSON, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: I think what you said is absolutely true, Neil. We're not having a genuine argument about the concerns around immigration. You would think that, after last week's misspeak by Sarah Huckabee Sanders, we would have recognized that there are other porous ports that are of equal concern, air and sea. And if we were having that genuine discussion about immigration, we would be addressing a comprehensive immigration plan, not the demagoguing that's been...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, we have done that in the past, right?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So I'm saying, is it your Democrats who sort of pooh-pooh or dismiss whether there's a crisis at the border have lied about it, that they -- in fact, there is a crisis? It's just in the eye of the beholder.

utterances.speaker: LEVENSON
utterances.sentences: I think we actually recognize that there's a comprehensive crisis that has to deal with paths of citizenship, that has to deal with our other ports.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But they're not open to the very wall that they were open up to before, right?

utterances.speaker: LEVENSON
utterances.sentences: Neil, the problem is, is that when you just talk about the wall, when you just talk about our southern borders, what you're doing is demonizing. You're creating demagoguery. You're creating this sense of, we're under siege from our southern borders. And that's just -- but that's...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: No, I hear you, Scott. But they're also talking about the common ground. I mean, you talk about comprehensive immigration reform. And, Shannon, we have been there before with Ronald Reagan, with Bill Clinton, with both Presidents Bush, and Barack Obama. And we never, ever get past go.

utterances.speaker: VAVRA
utterances.sentences: And one of the really interesting points I want to point out here is that Senator Mitch McConnell, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, has been totally bowing to President Trump's demands at this point. We saw him kind of sparring this morning with Senator Cardin and other Democrats on the Senate floor over whether they should use some of the House funding bills to reopen some of the government. And so that's an interesting point I want to pull out there.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And, by the way, they did. The House just approved a transportation and housing appropriations bill to that point, unanimous Democratic support; 12 GOPers voted for it as well. So, you're quite right on that. But it's going to take that kind of step- by-step movement to move the needle. Right?

utterances.speaker: VAVRA
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And I think, in the coming days -- as you said earlier in your show, on Saturday, we will surpass the record for the longest government shutdown in history. And that's going to start to probably feel -- put some pressure on both sides of the aisle here, on President Trump...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: No, I hear you. Noelle, do you think that the president did a huge disservice to Republicans, though, on this Mexican comment? No comment did this president make more often and in as many places as this idea that the Mexicans were going to pay for the wall. And to say today and dismiss it today, oh, I didn't mean they were going to write a check for it, then what the hell does pay for it mean?

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, if you will recall, this was a chant. Who's going to pay for the wall? Mexico is going to pay.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right. Right.

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: I mean, this was a chant at rallies. The president really does not like to admit he is wrong or that he misspoke.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: There's nothing wrong with admitting it. I built a career making big doozies.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I'm just telling you, I think the American people are very wise.

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And when they see this kind of stuff and remember the comments themselves that were made by both parties...

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: ... they're not going to rip them for things -- they acknowledge a mistake. I got it wrong. I thought they would pay for it, but I got it wrong, and beyond, and be done.

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: This is his personality, Neil. Right or wrong, this is his personality.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, he is not the only one.

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: He's not going to say he's wrong.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But I'm just saying, enough already.

utterances.speaker: NIKPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Guys, I want to thank you. I'm sorry to jump on all of you, but I'm -- I'm so angry that I might not eat dinner. And some of you are saying, that's probably a good idea.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: We will have more after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: He's worth close to $140 billion. And Jeff Bezos is now getting a divorce in an equal property state called Washington state. Split that empire. We will after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, the president on the border. He's going to be leaving McAllen, Texas, pretty soon. Former Arizona Governor Jan Brewer. Governor, what do you make of this back-and-forth on this? We have got a government essentially held hostage to this debate. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: JAN BREWER, R-ARIZ., FORMER GOVERNOR
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think that it is. I think that Congress and the president, they need to stay at home, and they need to go to the table and solve this problem. They ought to lock the doors and not let anybody out. The public wants our border security. We're tired of all the nonsense. And they need to do their job.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Now, would you recommend that, to get a comprehensive package, it's told that Republicans have to be more flexible on DACA, the children of the illegals who entered this country and, through no fault of their own, are kind of stuck in limbo here, and that more Republicans than have been generally acknowledged are on board with that? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: I agree. We know that we have a problem with DACA that needs to be resolved. And this is the time that we could do it, with President Trump's leadership. I think that he has said that he's offered up an agreement on it. But the Democrats just flat-out refuse to give President Trump a border wall and a partial payment. I mean, it's just absolutely ridiculous that this has gotten to the point where it has. We have dealt with this problem for decades.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Let me ask you, Governor, because the president used to say, as a candidate for president and then as president, that the Mexicans were going to pick up the tab for this. Now he says today, you misunderstood me. I never said they are going to write a check. But he did say consistently, dozens of times. I just picked up a few of them where he did say just that. So, if I'm a Democrat, I'm trying to strike a deal with this guy, wouldn't I say, wait a minute, you just lied?

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: Well, they have already called us all liars anyway.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, back and forth. You're quite right.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: Yes, right. And the bottom line is that the American public, they want our border security. It's the federal government's responsibility to fund it. And they need to figure...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But the American public thought that the Mexicans, under this president, would pick up the bill, right?

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know. Yes, he did. And I don't know what kind of deal that he thinks that he can do or is going to do in order to make sure that Mexico pays for the bill. But we know the money all comes out of the general fund, the federal government. And they need to get it done, and they need to get it now.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right. I understand what you're saying. Governor, let me ask you. Maybe there was something to what he said about we have this trade deal with Mexico. It's still not ratified yet. But we have a trade deal that would create some of the revenue.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Is that what he meant to pay for this? And then how would he use that to pay for this?

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: I don't know how -- well, how he meant that Mexico was going to pay for it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: But we know there's always tariffs, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera. Every government knows that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: And, eventually, maybe they will pay it. Maybe they will pay for it in trade with this new agreement. But the public is frustrated. And we need to get it done. And to just simply just no, no, no, no -- and he has negotiated, and he has compromised.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, where's the compromise been on his part? By not calling it a wall, or by saying the Mexicans are going to pay for it, not going to be it? Where? What's the biggest compromise you think the president has made?

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: They -- they -- they didn't want a cement wall, so now it's steel barrier wall.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Is that really a compromise?

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: He -- I think so.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: And I believe -- and I believe that Mexico will pay for it. I think they -- forget that. Move on. It -- just...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I like what you just said there, Governor. Forget that. Look at reality. Forget that and move on. And I think you're quite right. Move on. We all -- things evolve. Situations evolve.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: What has been said in the middle of a political campaign is one thing. Delivering the goods in reality as president is another, and we evolve. Move on, right?

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: We absolutely need to do that. And I think that leadership needs to lock people in a room.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: We do that at a state level. And not let anybody go home until it's a done deal.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, well, good luck with that. Governor, it's always good seeing you. Happy new year.

utterances.speaker: BREWER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Happy new year to you, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right. And, by the way, this goes for Democrats who said, what crisis? I don't see any crisis. More after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, they're already the world's richest couple, and now breaking up, they could be the number one and two richest people on the planet. FOX Business Network's Hillary Vaughn on what's happening at Amazon and team Bezos.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hey, Neil. Well, Jeff Bezos is about to lose his title is world's richest man. And he could lose as much as half of his net worth in this divorce, as his soon- to-be ex-wife is on track to become the world's richest woman. Bezos announcing on Twitter that he and his wife, MacKenzie Bezos, are divorcing after 25 years of marriage. TMZ reports that Bezos did not have a prenup, and the couple will file for divorce in Washington state. That's a community property state, where assets are split 50/50. It's not just Bezos' personal wealth that's at stake here, though. Control of his company, Amazon, could be up for grabs too. Right now, Bezos is worth $137 billion and owns about 16 percent of Amazon. MacKenzie could be entitled to more than $66 billion. And if she opts for a payout, Bezos could have to sell or pledge some of his shares, diluting his control of Amazon. Bezos also owns The Washington Post. He also has the space company Blue Origin, and also significant investments in companies like Airbnb, Twitter, Uber, and Nextdoor and a handful of other companies. So, either way, no matter who gets what's here, there's a lot of money to go around, and this probably will go down as the most expensive divorce in history to date -- Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But both parties apparently want it to be amicable. We will see what happens. Hillary, thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: VAUGHN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Let's get the read on this. FOX News legal eagle Mercedes Colwin. We have got FOX News contributor Kat Timpf and Internet radio sensation Mike Gunzelman. Mike, it's supposed to be friendly.

utterances.speaker: MIKE GUNZELMAN, INTERNET RADIO HOST
utterances.sentences: You hate to see this. You really hate to this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Then why are you smiling?

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, Jeff -- can I call you Jeffrey? You idiot. You are -- you're go with a prenup. Why? Because love stinks. It's not real.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: They have been married for 25 years.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: No, no, it doesn't matter. You are an idiot. You deserve everything that you're getting and more right now. And, Neil, I just hope this doesn't affect the cost of my Amazon Prime membership. It better not go...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Always back...

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Always back to me.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: That's one thing where Don Imus was right about you, always about you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Mercedes, legally, it's a -- what do they call it, a share state, right? What's the term they use?

utterances.speaker: MERCEDES COLWIN, LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: The shares that are at stake?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, where you share, you split down the middle.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. So it could be equitable distribution. But this is -- this is a community property state, so it's down the middle.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Down the middle, and then that applies to whatever wealth you have accumulated or stock you own or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Exactly, accumulated during the marriage. And funnily enough -- because, when Ron Perelman asked -- they said, well, why is why is divorce so expensive, his response was like, because it's worth it. And that's really what it boils down to. This is the price of freedom. The big issue, though, here is that most of his wealth is based on stock. That's why this whole issue about Amazon really comes into play. Most of his wealth is on stock. That means that he may have to pledge half of that, of his wealth, meaning the stock. Then he starts to lose control of the company. So you start to see the instability.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And that, by the way, got -- the reason why we're doing this, because it's a great business story, America. We're not interested in the sordid details of this.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, who wants that, right?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But, all of a sudden, if he had to sell a lot -- I mean, that could affect shareholders and all that. Kat, is your sense, though, that they have given -- as a couple, they have given the indication that they want this to be amicable, they're still remaining friends, et cetera, et cetera, so that this might not become a soap opera?

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: I think that's what everyone says at first. But I think that an amicable divorce is quite often a myth. I think that, especially if you're going to be losing half your money -- I mean, in this culture, in this culture, we tend to...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Half your money is still leaving you with...

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Seventy billion dollars.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: But he used to be able to do ridiculous stuff. Like, he could start a lemur breeding business. He could start -- he could still do that, but maybe not as large of a one.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You can do that with $70 billion.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: In our culture, we tend to focus on all the good aspects of love. It's so great to fall in love and love is all you need.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: We still believe in love.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Love can destroy you more than anything else can.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: All I can say, I would do a lot and wake up next to anybody for $70 billion, or $70, either way, whatever comes first.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Are you propositioning? I think you're propositioning.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It wouldn't even have to be human.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: This is a family show.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Legally, I'm just curious. I mean, is it automatic that assets are shared? You have had others in states where they are supposed to go 50/50, where the divorcing spouse leaves the other spouse, usually a woman, with a tidy sum, but certainly not half.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: I mean, there are changes. There could be changes. I mean, one, it really depends on what they're going to do. There are four kids here. So there is going to be some -- at least some effort to be amicable, to have this split be amicable. So if it does get litigated, it is going to get super messy, because we're talking about the stock, we're talking about the property. And he may be forced to sell the stock. If not, the judge may step in and say, look, it still has to be equitable and just. So that's really the standard here. And is it equitable and just?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Twenty-five years ago, that was that was the launch of this juggernaut. And then so it all started in those married years, right?

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Right, the prenup, you mean?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Oh, sure. The prenup wasn't really -- it wasn't really bandied about 25 years ago, to your point. It really wasn't.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: He's all of a sudden pontificating like he's Perry Mason here.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: But here's the thing. You need to do the prenup, because like what happens if you hit the -- I play Mega Millions all the time, because I want to become a millionaire. But you don't know if that's going to happen after you get married. So, get the prenup first.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, wait a minute.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: How romantic is that, Jeff? Seriously, is that romantic?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You hook up with someone, you're going to demand a prenup? Because you would be lucky to find someone to put up with you.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: It's the first question on the date. Do you believe in prenups? No? Check, please. Let's go.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Nice. Very romantic.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: You got to do it, right?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Well, there's nothing romantic about losing half your fortune either.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But isn't a prenup pre-gauging that your relationship won't last?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Well, sure. But you know what? You get to keep more money. And this is proof that, even after 25 wonderful years, love can still die.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: And when there's another woman involved.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: There is another woman involved.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Allegedly.

utterances.speaker: COLWIN
utterances.sentences: Allegedly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So we shall see. Thank you very, very much. Gunz, I'm extremely worried about you.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Story of my life. It's going to be a bad 2019.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Thanks, guys. And, again, that notion -- of course, Mercedes raised this as well -- this idea that, as an Amazon shareholder, you might have to concern yourself with it, because if the big boss has to unload a lot of stock, then who buys that stock? Usually, it's depressive for the stock. It was a little bit today. We will watch it very, very closely, because it's a great business story. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, the bottom line is, a wall matters, security matters, what people are passionate about on either party, that matters. But family physician Dr. Jennifer Caudle joins me right now to say, you know what, what also matters, what happens in a shutdown. And what's happening in this one worries the good doctor a great deal. Doctor, thanks for taking the time.

utterances.speaker: DR. JENNIFER CAUDLE, FAMILY PHYSICIAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: What's happening right now? Now, for the FDA, it kind of handicaps them, right? Explain what happens.

utterances.speaker: CAUDLE
utterances.sentences: Well, in a government shutdown, so many organizations and agencies are changed. And we're seeing that also with the FDA. As a family doctor, I am concerned about this. The FDA does a lot of things. And to be clear, there are a lot of services that will continue. There are some, rather, some of their emergency services, et cetera. They will respond in outbreaks, et cetera. But I think one of the things that definitely has made so many others concerned is the change in routine food evaluations and food investigations. So, we know that foreign foods will still be inspected. But the problem is, the routine investigation, inspection of domestic foods, that's what's kind of changing right now. And that does have me worried a little bit.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, so from food inspections to just policing what's going through processing plants and cattle facilities and grain facilities and all, it's not as if that stops, but there isn't the man or woman power to keep on top of it to the degree we used to, right?

utterances.speaker: CAUDLE
utterances.sentences: Right. Well, right. And that's what's happening. So, in this time where we don't have the manpower that we used to have -- and I should say the commissioner of the FDA has been very helpful with all of his tweets. He's been tweeting about what they're doing. Again, we're still doing foreign food inspections. What the commissioner, Dr. Gottlieb, is trying to do is to continue high-risk domestic food inspections, which I think is a good idea. Higher-risk foods will be things like cheeses, fruits and vegetables, infant formula, medical foods and things like that. That's going to be very important. But those are -- the routine food inspections are not necessarily going to happen the way they had before. And this is my thing. We have foodborne illness outbreaks in times where we do have food inspections. Foodborne illness outbreaks happen already. I'm just concerned and wondering what's going to happen when we don't have that manpower able to investigate and inspect sort of our routine food supply the same.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But it's beyond just the food, right? You reminded me and others have in the past here that it also affects simple drugs and availability and tests and all the rest, that that is...

utterances.speaker: CAUDLE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: ... while not directly affected, the indirect funding that goes to the National Institute of Health and some of these others that get private and public funding, that kind of enters a Twilight Zone, right?

utterances.speaker: CAUDLE
utterances.sentences: Well, no, you're right. And it's not just food. I definitely do want to be clear. It's cold medications, prescriptions, generic drugs, prescription drugs. Now, let me be clear. It's not all stopping.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAUDLE
utterances.sentences: And, actually, the HHS.gov Web site actually has a very, very good description of the services that will continue and those that will stop. Not all services are stopping. But the ones that I think are sort of on the higher priority list, I think about our food supply. I think about people going to the grocery store.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Good point.

utterances.speaker: CAUDLE
utterances.sentences: And that's something I think about and wondering how we proceed in this time, certainly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: That's well-put. Dr. Caudle, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: CAUDLE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I needed that perspective. We all did. And, as the doctor pointed out, it's not just food. It's for those trying to close on an FHA-backed loan, you can't, so the closing is delayed. A lot of these Wall Street guys who are salivating at companies going public, they can't because the Securities and Exchange Commission is kind of decommissioned, and on and on. And it spreads further and further and further. There are people who are passionate about those issues, just as much as there are people passionate about a wall, just as there those who are passionate about not building a wall. You see, everyone has their passions. Everyone has their issues, but everyone can't be in the front of the line. More after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You ever get the sense that Wall Street kind of realizes this shutdown is just Kabuki theater, and they're all playing fast and loose with the facts and their passions and games? Because we were up today, a fifth straight session we have been up. Haven't done that since last October. And that's because the markets are thinking this will resolve itself. Bigger issues, like trade, stable interest rates, hopefully better earnings, and that's what they're betting their money on. How about you? "The Five" is now.
